title: How to Make a Practical Housewarming Gift

steps.headline: Identify the homeowner’s life stage before shopping for items.
steps.description: For a first time home owner, the basics such as screwdrivers, extension cords and tape measures are a great idea. However, if this is the homeowner’s second, third or even fourth home, you may want to stuff the gift with items that may be specific to either the new area or home (for instance, moving from a large home to a condo).

steps.headline: Consider adding a special touch.
steps.description: In addition to the practical, find at least one item that may have function, but also is unique and/or speaks to the individual homeowner’s taste. For example, if the homeowners have a fondness for all things British, include a Union Jack hand towel in the jar or Royal Family coasters. Gift cards to home improvement or bed and bath stores are also a good idea and add a special touch.

steps.headline: Don’t overwhelm the jar.
steps.description: The idea is to give a gift that has thought and function but not to provide all the tools they need. For instance, instead of the value-pack of nails opt for a smaller pack. If the homeowner needs more, he or she can get them--the idea is to offer something to get the homeowner started.

steps.headline: Shop for the container first.
steps.description:
Before you fill the container, you need to know the size and amount you can add. Consider purchasing a container that can also be re-purposed and used later to hold a variety of items but something that isn’t so big the homeowner will need to find a place for storage. Make sure the container either has a lid or can be sealed. You can also seal the top with a piece of fabric and ribbon if you fall in love with the container and think the homeowner will too. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b1\/Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/b\/b1\/Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/aid3458058-v4-728px-Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Purchase gift items.
steps.description: Gather items to fit inside the container and envision everything someone might need during those initial days in a new home. Consider making a list before you shop and possibly bring the container along for the shopping spree to ensure everything fits inside. Consider going with a theme for your gift, such as a picture hanging theme. Purchase everything needed to hang multiple pictures/paintings in the home including a mini hammer or small electric screwdriver. Don’t over-spend on items, especially if you aren’t sure whether the homeowner already owns the item or not. For example, don't purchase the top-of-the-line screwdriver in the event the homeowner already has one (or may have one in storage or packed in boxes).

steps.headline: Remember to get your specialty item.
steps.description: This item will hopefully be positioned front and center inside the jar so make sure it is sized accordingly and fits amongst the other items.

steps.headline: Remove price tags from purchased items.
steps.description: Depending on how the tags are placed, either use a razor blade to lift tag stickers or you can cut away the area of the package that contains the sticker. Using a black Sharpie marker to black out the price may also be a solution.

steps.headline: Examine packaged items to ensure they fit nicely inside the container.
steps.description: In some cases you may want to remove the item and allow it to free-float inside the jar. For example, a screwdriver or mini hammer can be removed from the packaging to accommodate for space.

steps.headline: Place items inside container.
steps.description:
There’s no special way to do this, however make sure everything fits comfortably, leaving space for the special item to be positioned toward the front/outside of the container. When positioning special item, slide it in last and make sure you can see it after everything is in place. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9a\/Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-9Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/9\/9a\/Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-9Bullet1.jpg\/aid3458058-v4-728px-Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":315,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"498","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Add lid and seal.
steps.description:
If you are using a standard lid, just screw lid on and add a ribbon. Consider including a gift tag along with the ribbon. This can include a special message from you and/or a list of items inside the container. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c8\/Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/c\/c8\/Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/aid3458058-v4-728px-Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

text:
Assess Homeowner’s Needs Identify the homeowner’s life stage before shopping for items. For a first time home owner, the basics such as screwdrivers, extension cords and tape measures are a great idea. However, if this is the homeowner’s second, third or even fourth home, you may want to stuff the gift with items that may be specific to either the new area or home (for instance, moving from a large home to a condo). Consider adding a special touch. In addition to the practical, find at least one item that may have function, but also is unique and/or speaks to the individual homeowner’s taste. For example, if the homeowners have a fondness for all things British, include a Union Jack hand towel in the jar or Royal Family coasters. Gift cards to home improvement or bed and bath stores are also a good idea and add a special touch. Don’t overwhelm the jar. The idea is to give a gift that has thought and function but not to provide all the tools they need. For instance, instead of the value-pack of nails opt for a smaller pack. If the homeowner needs more, he or she can get them--the idea is to offer something to get the homeowner started. Gather Items Shop for the container first. Before you fill the container, you need to know the size and amount you can add. Consider purchasing a container that can also be re-purposed and used later to hold a variety of items but something that isn’t so big the homeowner will need to find a place for storage. Make sure the container either has a lid or can be sealed. You can also seal the top with a piece of fabric and ribbon if you fall in love with the container and think the homeowner will too. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/b/b1/Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/aid3458058-v4-728px-Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

"} Purchase gift items. Gather items to fit inside the container and envision everything someone might need during those initial days in a new home. Consider making a list before you shop and possibly bring the container along for the shopping spree to ensure everything fits inside. Consider going with a theme for your gift, such as a picture hanging theme. Purchase everything needed to hang multiple pictures/paintings in the home including a mini hammer or small electric screwdriver. Don’t over-spend on items, especially if you aren’t sure whether the homeowner already owns the item or not. For example, don't purchase the top-of-the-line screwdriver in the event the homeowner already has one (or may have one in storage or packed in boxes). Remember to get your specialty item. This item will hopefully be positioned front and center inside the jar so make sure it is sized accordingly and fits amongst the other items. Build Your Gift Remove price tags from purchased items. Depending on how the tags are placed, either use a razor blade to lift tag stickers or you can cut away the area of the package that contains the sticker. Using a black Sharpie marker to black out the price may also be a solution. Examine packaged items to ensure they fit nicely inside the container. In some cases you may want to remove the item and allow it to free-float inside the jar. For example, a screwdriver or mini hammer can be removed from the packaging to accommodate for space. Place items inside container. There’s no special way to do this, however make sure everything fits comfortably, leaving space for the special item to be positioned toward the front/outside of the container. When positioning special item, slide it in last and make sure you can see it after everything is in place. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-9Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/9/9a/Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-9Bullet1.jpg/aid3458058-v4-728px-Make-a-Practical-Housewarming-Gift-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":315,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"498","licensing":"

tyn_model: home improvement or bed and bath stores
